posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
So Controls section 6.9 page 61 along with the various source code bits in wpilib has lead me to believe that kg / ka should ideally be 9.8 m/s^2.

When I perform the calculation I get something like 0.26 m/s^2.  I wondered if there was some other force acting on the system.

I did a simple unpowered “free fall drop” of the elevator and with a stopwatch got something akin to 0.2 m / s^2.  So I’m not loosing my mind.

Other than other sources of friction could back emf electromagnetic braking be the culprit.  I would then make the assumption that this was absorbed into the sysId characterization tests?

Here are my feedforward gains

static final double ksVolts = 0.13384; static final double kgVolts = 0.16143; static final double kvVoltsPerMPS = 17.619; static final double kaVoltsPerMPSSquared = 0.61528;
For an error of that size I’d check your units, other forces aren’t likely to change things by two orders of magnitude.

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked: For what it’s worth, k_g/k_a being 9.8 m/s² is an assumption on our part. It was accurate for 3512’s 2019 elevator at least. Motor back-EMF and gearbox friction can slow things down significantly.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
I mean that’s good.  I’m not loosing my mind.  This doesn’t effect elevator feedforward does it?

Our usage of motion planning, feedforward and feedback seems to indicate as such.  I guess since motor back-emf is linear the model would still hold.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: wouldn’t gearbox friction be accounted for in ks or is there another type of friction that isn’t accounted for?

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
narmstro:

gearbox friction

There are frictions to go from zero to non-zero, spin without load, and load dependent.
